title: Isner–Mahut match at the 2010 Wimbledon Championships
text:
The Isner–Mahut match at the 2010 Wimbledon Championships is notable as the <a href="Longest%20tennis%20match%20records">longest tennis match in history</a>. It was a first-round <a href="2010%20Wimbledon%20Championships%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20Singles">Men's Singles</a> match, in which the American 23rd seed <a href="John%20Isner">John Isner</a> played against French <a href="Glossary%20of%20tennis%23Qualifier">qualifier</a> <a href="Nicolas%20Mahut">Nicolas Mahut</a>. The match began at 6:13 pm (<a href="British%20Summer%20Time">British Summer Time</a>, or 17:13 <a href="Coordinated%20Universal%20Time">UTC</a>) on Tuesday, 2010, on Court 18 at Wimbledon. At , due to the fading daylight, play was suspended before the start of the fifth set. After resuming on Wednesday, 23 June, at , the record for longest match was broken at . Play continued until the final set was tied at 59 games all, at which point the daylight faded again, and so play was suspended once more at . Play resumed again at on Thursday, 24 June, and eventually Isner won the match at , the final set having lasted for 8 hours, 11 minutes.
In total, the match took 11 hours, 5 minutes of play over three days, with a final score of 6–4, 3–6, 6–7(7–9), 7–6(7–3), 70–68 for a total of 183 games. It remains, by far, the <a href="longest%20tennis%20match%20records">longest match in tennis history</a>, measured both by time duration and also by number of games. The final set alone was longer than the previous record for longest match.
Both players broke numerous Wimbledon and <a href="Longest%20tennis%20match%20records">tennis records</a>, including each serving over 100 <a href="ace%20%28tennis%29">ace</a>s, with the match being referred to as "the endless match." 
A rule change instituted for the <a href="2019%20Wimbledon%20Championships">2019 Championships</a>, introducing a <a href="tie%20break">tie break</a> in the fifth set (or third set for women's matches), means that the Isner–Mahut match will remain the longest match in Wimbledon tournament history in terms of games played, barring any future rule change. 
Currently, the <a href="French%20Open">French Open</a> remains as the only Grand Slam tennis tournament that still has no tiebreaker system for the deciding set.
Background.
The match took place during the <a href="2010%20Wimbledon%20Championships">2010 edition</a> of the 13-day Wimbledon Championships, held every June and July. Mahut, who was not ranked high enough to qualify for the tournament automatically, earned his place by winning in the qualifying pre-tournament, where he was <a href="Seed%20%28tennis%29">seeded</a> 27th. He played three qualification rounds, beating <a href="Frank%20Dancevic">Frank Dancevic</a> 6–3, 6–0, in the first round, then <a href="Alex%20Bogdanovic">Alex Bogdanovic</a> 3–6, 6–3, 24–22, and finally <a href="Stefan%20Koubek">Stefan Koubek</a> in five sets, 6–7(8), 3–6, 6–3, 6–4, 6–4.
Having played through the qualifying stage, Mahut was <a href="2010%20Wimbledon%20Championships%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20Singles%23Section%208">drawn against</a> Isner in the first round of the Men's Singles. Their match was scheduled for Court 18, one of the larger outer courts at Wimbledon.
The match.
Details.
The match started on the tournament's second day. As in all men's <a href="Grand%20Slam%20%28tennis%29">Grand Slam</a> matches, the match was played as <a href="Tennis%20score">best of five sets</a>. In the first four <a href="set%20%28tennis%29">sets</a> of a match, a <a href="tiebreak%20%28tennis%29">tiebreaker</a> is used to decide a tied set; however, as of 2010, this did not apply in the fifth set except at the <a href="US%20Open%20%28tennis%29">US Open</a>. Thus, in the event of a tie in the fifth set, the players would continue to play the set until one of them led by two <a href="game%20%28tennis%29">games</a>.
The first four sets passed without significant incident. Isner won the first set 6–4, breaking Mahut's serve in the ninth game of the set after Mahut had twice double faulted. Mahut took the second set 6–3, having broken Isner's serve to love in the second game of the set. The third and fourth sets had no breaks of serve and were both decided by tiebreaks, with Mahut winning the third set tiebreak 9–7, and Isner winning the fourth set tiebreak 7–3, leaving the score at two sets each. At the end of the fourth set, the match was halted due to darkness.
Resuming on , it soon became the longest match ever. Isner failed to convert four match points on this day, the first when Mahut was serving at 9–10, the second and third when Mahut was serving at 32–33, and the fourth in the dramatic last game that they played at 58–59 on , with Mahut initially serving up 40–15 for the hold. Mahut also failed to convert two break points on Isner's serve, at 50–50. The match was suspended for a second time because of darkness on the evening of at 59–59 in the fifth set despite chants of "We want more, we want more" from the spectators.
Isner drank a "<a href="sports%20drink">recovery shake</a>" and took an <a href="cryotherapy">ice bath</a>. Fellow American <a href="Andy%20Roddick">Andy Roddick</a> brought <a href="take-out">take-out food</a> for him and his coach, including "three boxes of pizza, all sorts of chicken and mashed potatoes"; Isner said later that he was so hungry he "could have eaten 12 Big Macs", but reported that drinking coconut water helped him <a href="Fluid%20replacement">rehydrate</a> and avoid the <a href="cramping">cramping</a> that he had experienced in the past. He slept for less than four hours before rising. Mahut also slept for only a few hours, and had a cold bath and a <a href="massage">massage</a>. The next morning, the BBC reported that Mahut had been practising and <a href="Andy%20Murray">Andy Murray</a> informed them that Isner had been running on a treadmill before play resumed.
The match was resumed on , and both players continued to dominate their service games. With Isner serving at 68–68, Mahut went up 0–30, but Isner won 4 points in a row to hold serve. At 68–69, with Mahut serving at 15–15, Mahut netted a <a href="drop%20shot">drop shot</a> that would likely have won the point. Isner, far back in the court at the time, later said that he would not have had the energy to chase after that shot. At 30–30, Isner passed Mahut at the net with a difficult inside-out forehand from the middle of the court that landed just inside the line. This brought up Isner's fifth match point (his first on 24 June) and his 14th break point of the match, which Isner converted with a down-the-line backhand passing shot. Thus, after 67 minutes of play on the third day of the match, Isner won the deciding final set, 70–68. The entire match over the 3 days lasted 11 hours and 5 minutes. This new world record for the longest match ever was 4 hours and 32 minutes longer than the previous record, the first-round match between <a href="Fabrice%20Santoro">Fabrice Santoro</a> and <a href="Arnaud%20Cl%C3%A9ment">Arnaud Clément</a> at the <a href="2004%20French%20Open%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20Singles">2004 French Open</a>, which had lasted 6 hours, 33 minutes.
Officials.
The <a href="Official%20%28tennis%29%23Chair%20umpire">chair umpire</a> throughout the match was the <a href="Sweden">Swedish</a> official <a href="Mohamed%20Lahyani">Mohamed Lahyani</a>. Lahyani said afterwards that he was so "gripped by the amazing match" that his concentration stayed solid and he did not think about eating or going to the toilet. On the second day of the match, two groups of 14 <a href="Official%20%28tennis%29%23Line%20umpire">linespeople</a> and four groups of 28 <a href="ballboy">ballboys and ballgirls</a> were used in a rotation. At the end of the match, Lahyani announced the score incorrectly, accidentally switching the scores of the two tie-break sets.
Failing scoreboard.
On the second day of play, the courtside <a href="scoreboard">scoreboard</a> stood still at 47–47 and later went dark. <a href="IBM">IBM</a> programmers said it was only programmed to go to 47–47 but would be fixed by the next day. The online scoreboard at the official website lasted slightly longer; it was reset at 50–50. Users were asked to "please add 50 to the Isner/Mahut game score". An IBM programmer worked on a <a href="hotfix">hotfix</a> for the scoring system until to accommodate the match's scores for the next day, although it would have again malfunctioned had the match gone beyond 25 more games.
Aftermath.
Special recognition.
Immediately after the match, both players and the umpire were presented with a crystal bowl and champagne flutes by <a href="Tim%20Henman">Tim Henman</a> and <a href="Ann%20Haydon-Jones">Ann Haydon-Jones</a> on behalf of the <a href="All%20England%20Lawn%20Tennis%20and%20Croquet%20Club">All England Club</a>, as special recognition of the match. The players were then interviewed on court by <a href="John%20Inverdale">John Inverdale</a>, before a photocall for the press alongside one of the two Court 18 scoreboards showing the score. Mahut subsequently donated memorabilia from the match for display at the <a href="International%20Tennis%20Hall%20of%20Fame">International Tennis Hall of Fame's Museum</a> in <a href="Newport%2C%20Rhode%20Island">Newport, Rhode Island</a>.
On 14 July, Isner and Mahut were jointly awarded the 2010 <a href="ESPY%20Award">ESPY Award</a> for "Best Record-Breaking Performance", beating fellow nominees <a href="Roger%20Federer">Roger Federer</a> and <a href="Usain%20Bolt">Usain Bolt</a>. Isner accepted the award in Los Angeles on behalf of both men.
In addition, the AELTC placed a plaque commemorating the match at Court 18. <a href="Time%20%28magazine%29">"Time"</a> named this match one of the Top 10 Sports Moments of 2010.
Players' subsequent schedules.
As the winner, Isner advanced to the second round where, on the day following the conclusion of his match with Mahut, he played <a href="Thiemo%20de%20Bakker">Thiemo de Bakker</a> on 25 June at on Court 5. The match was originally scheduled for 24 June but was postponed due to the continuance of Isner's first-round match against Mahut. De Bakker also had a lengthy first-round match against <a href="Santiago%20Giraldo">Santiago Giraldo</a>, winning by a score of 16–14 in the fifth set, but unlike Isner, he had a day off before his second-round match. Isner lost to De Bakker 0–6, 3–6, 2–6 in just 74 minutes. It was the shortest men's Wimbledon match at that point in 2010, and Isner failed to serve a single ace. Isner was visibly exhausted and required medical treatment for neck and shoulder problems throughout the match.
Isner was also due to play a doubles match with his partner <a href="Sam%20Querrey">Sam Querrey</a> on 24 June (against <a href="Micha%C5%82%20Przysi%C4%99%C5%BCny">Michał Przysiężny</a> and <a href="Dudi%20Sela">Dudi Sela</a>), but it was postponed to 25 June. Isner's doubles match was tentatively scheduled as the second match of that day on Court 19 following another men's doubles match; however, they withdrew from the doubles because Isner had a blister on his toe. After being eliminated from the tournament, Isner said, "I'll watch sports, I'll take in the <a href="2010%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a>, I'll go fishing, I'll do whatever. Just anything away from the tennis court."
As for Mahut, his doubles match with partner <a href="Arnaud%20Cl%C3%A9ment">Arnaud Clément</a> against <a href="Colin%20Fleming">Colin Fleming</a> and <a href="Ken%20Skupski">Ken Skupski</a> started late in the evening on 24 June (also on Court 18); the match was suspended after Mahut and Clément had lost the first set. On 25 June, Mahut/Clément – Fleming/Skupski was scheduled as the fourth match on Court 18 because Clément had a third-round singles match on Centre Court against <a href="Roger%20Federer">Roger Federer</a>. Because the match between <a href="Daniel%20Brands">Daniel Brands</a> and <a href="Victor%20H%C4%83nescu">Victor Hănescu</a> lasted almost 3 hours, 30 minutes and ended around 8:45 pm local time, the doubles match was postponed again; it was rescheduled as the first match on Court 14 on 26 June. On resumption, Fleming/Skupski defeated Mahut/Clément, 7–6, 6–4, 3–6, 7–6.
The two next met at the <a href="2011%20Hopman%20Cup">2011 Hopman Cup</a> exhibition in <a href="Perth%2C%20Western%20Australia">Perth</a>. Isner broke in the opening game to record a win in straight sets. They met again at the <a href="2011%20Wimbledon%20Championships">2011 Wimbledon Championships</a>, again in the first round. The odds of the unseeded players meeting in another first round match was 1 in 142. Isner won "Isner–Mahut II" in straight sets (7–6, 6–2, 7–6), in 2 hours and 3 minutes.
Reaction.
Former players and commentators have called the match historic and unlikely to happen again; many also praised both participants. <a href="John%20McEnroe">John McEnroe</a> said, "This is the greatest advertisement for our sport. It makes me proud to be a part of it. We often don't get the respect we deserve in tennis for the athletic demands it places on players, but this should push that respect way up".
Other players, former players, officials, media commentators and fans also praised the behaviour of both players. <a href="Roger%20Federer">Roger Federer</a> said of the match, "It's so impressive to see. I mean, I was watching this. I don't know if I was crying or laughing. It was too much". Federer also added, "This is absolutely amazing. [...] This is beyond anything". <a href="Novak%20Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a> extolled both players, saying, "You have to give them credit, both of them. Whoever wins today, I think both of them are winners".
"Sports Illustrated"'s Jon Wertheim said that the victory might give Isner a <a href="sports%20psychology">self-esteem boost</a>. McEnroe speculated, however, that the match might have shortened Isner and Mahut's careers by six months. A <a href="sports%20medicine">sports surgeon</a> said the players had risked <a href="dehydration">dehydration</a>, <a href="hyperthermia">hyperthermia</a>, and <a href="Nephropathy">kidney damage</a> during the long match, and that one or both might suffer "some sort of injury or persistent problem over the next six months [...] shoulder problems, <a href="tendonitis">tendonitis</a>, and recurrent knee problems", as well as the inability to "get into a groove" mentally for up to a year. Mahut revealed that following the match, he spent three months suffering from <a href="Major%20depressive%20disorder">depression</a> and a back injury.
Mahut shared his experiences on the match in the book "Le match de ma vie" ("The Match of My Life"), which he co-wrote with Philippe Bouin. The book was published in 2011.
Rule change.
In October 2018, three months after another marathon match featuring Isner – this time against <a href="Kevin%20Anderson%20%28tennis%29">Kevin Anderson</a> in the semifinals of <a href="2018%20Wimbledon%20Championships%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20Singles">2018 Wimbledon</a>, which Anderson won 7–6(8–6), 6–7(5–7), 6–7(9–11), 6–4, 26–24 after 6 hours and 36 minutes, the All England Club announced that Wimbledon would be introducing a rule change to prevent such long matches occurring in the future. Since <a href="2019%20Wimbledon%20Championships">2019 Wimbledon</a>, tie breaks are played at Wimbledon if the final set score is 12–all. This point was determined following a review of matches in the previous 20 tournaments and a consultation with players and officials. The rule was first used in the singles in the <a href="2019%20Wimbledon%20Championships%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20singles%20final">2019 Wimbledon final</a> between <a href="Roger%20Federer">Roger Federer</a> and <a href="Novak%20Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a>, after their fifth set ended that way.
Further recognition.
Wimbledon had planned to recognize the players on the 10th anniversary of the match, but was unable to do so owing to their decision to cancel the 2020 Wimbledon Championships in the wake of the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>. Instead, Wimbledon posted video coverage of the match in its entirety on its <a href="YouTube">YouTube</a> channel. In lieu of an in-person reunion, John Isner and Nicholas Mahut celebrated their anniversary via social networks. Isner joked about Mahut's hairstyle: "Nicolas Mahut, I can't believe it's been 10 years. Your hair hasn't moved an inch yet!" For his part, Mahut replied: "Happy birthday friend John Isner. We should take some time together to remember that amazing story."
In popular culture.
The chorus of <a href="Dan%20Bern">Dan Bern</a>'s song about the match concludes with the scores of the five sets: "six-four, three-six, six-seven, seven-six, seventy-sixtyeight". An <a href="a%20cappella">a cappella</a> performance of "Isner & Mahut" recorded in 2010 appears on Bern's album "Live in New York".
HBO released a <a href="mockumentary">mockumentary</a> in 2015 titled "<a href="7%20Days%20in%20Hell">7 Days in Hell</a>", starring <a href="Andy%20Samberg">Andy Samberg</a> and <a href="Kit%20Harington">Kit Harington</a> as two professional tennis players who face off in what becomes the longest match in history. The match takes place at Wimbledon in 2001. The film was inspired by the Isner–Mahut match and included former and current professional tennis players in cameo roles playing themselves, including <a href="John%20McEnroe">John McEnroe</a>, <a href="Chris%20Evert">Chris Evert</a> and <a href="Serena%20Williams">Serena Williams</a>.
This match also has a mention in <a href="Mr.%20B%20The%20Gentleman%20Rhymer">Mr. B The Gentleman Rhymer</a>'s 2016 song "Open String" from the album "There's a Rumpus Going On".
The 2018 novel "Chance to Break" by <a href="Owen%20Prell">Owen Prell</a> builds its narrative climax around the Isner–Mahut match.
Records.
The match set at least eleven tennis records:
The previous record for games played in a match was the 122-game <a href="1973%20Davis%20Cup">1973 Davis Cup</a> match in which the <a href="United%20States%20Davis%20Cup%20team">United States</a> team of <a href="Stan%20Smith">Stan Smith</a> and <a href="Erik%20van%20Dillen">Erik van Dillen</a> defeated the <a href="Chile%20Davis%20Cup%20team">Chile</a> team of <a href="Patricio%20Cornejo">Patricio Cornejo</a> and <a href="Jaime%20Fillol">Jaime Fillol</a> 7–9, 37–39, 8–6, 6–1, 6–3. The previous record for most games in a singles match was the 112-game <a href="1969%20Wimbledon%20Championships">1969</a> match in which <a href="Pancho%20Gonzales">Pancho Gonzales</a> defeated <a href="Charlie%20Pasarell">Charlie Pasarell</a> 22–24, 1–6, 16–14, 6–3, 11–9, also in the first round at Wimbledon. The singles record since the introduction of the <a href="Tennis%20score%23History%20of%20the%20tiebreak">tie-break</a> was the 2003 <a href="Australian%20Open">Australian Open</a> quarter-final match, in which <a href="Andy%20Roddick">Andy Roddick</a> and <a href="Younes%20El%20Aynaoui">Younes El Aynaoui</a> played 83 games; Roddick won 4–6, 7–6(5), 4–6, 6–4, 21–19.
The previous official record for duration was set at the <a href="2004%20French%20Open">2004 French Open</a> when <a href="Fabrice%20Santoro">Fabrice Santoro</a> defeated <a href="Arnaud%20Cl%C3%A9ment">Arnaud Clément</a> 6–4, 6–3, 6–7(5), 3–6, 16–14, in 6 hours, 33 minutes. The unofficial record of 6 hours, 40 minutes, was set on 2009, when <a href="Chris%20Eaton%20%28tennis%29">Chris Eaton</a> defeated <a href="James%20Ward%20%28tennis%29">James Ward</a> 6–3, 6–2, 6–7(3), 2–6, 21–19 in a playoff match to represent the <a href="Great%20Britain%20Davis%20Cup%20team">Great Britain Davis Cup team</a> in a <a href="2009%20Davis%20Cup%20Europe/Africa%20Zone%20Group%20I%23Ukraine%20vs.%20Great%20Britain">2009 Davis Cup Europe/Africa Zone Group I second round tie versus Ukraine</a>. Isner–Mahut's fifth set alone lasted some 90 minutes longer than the previous longest match. Indeed, even that portion of the fifth set played on the second day was about half an hour longer than the previous longest match, so it also broke the record for the longest play in a single day.
John Isner served his 79th ace to take the final set to 39–38 with serve. This surpassed <a href="Ivo%20Karlovi%C4%87">Ivo Karlović</a>'s 78 aces that he served on 2009 in a <a href="Davis%20Cup">Davis Cup</a> match against <a href="Radek%20%C5%A0t%C4%9Bp%C3%A1nek">Radek Štěpánek</a>. In all, Isner served 113 aces; Mahut also surpassed the previous record with 103 aces. At the 2012 edition of Wimbledon, <a href="Serena%20Williams">Serena Williams</a> had a women's record 102 aces for the entire tournament, falling short of both Isner's and Mahut's aces in a single round.
The length of the match exceeded the total playing time of <a href="Serena%20Williams">Serena Williams</a> in every round combined in winning the previous year's Ladies Wimbledon title. She played for less than ten hours in the entire tournament.
Coverage.
In the United Kingdom, the match was featured live in part on <a href="BBC%20One">BBC One</a>, <a href="BBC%20Two">BBC Two</a> and <a href="BBC%20HD">BBC HD</a>, which were all the television channels which the <a href="BBC">BBC</a> used to cover Wimbledon. The match was broadcast live in its entirety on the <a href="BBC%20Red%20Button">BBC Red Button</a>.
Commentating for the BBC during this match were <a href="Ronald%20McIntosh">Ronald McIntosh</a> and <a href="Mark%20Cox%20%28tennis%29">Mark Cox</a> on the first day, and McIntosh and <a href="Greg%20Rusedski">Greg Rusedski</a> on the second and third days. It was McIntosh's first ever Wimbledon commentary and became the longest continuous commentary for a single match in broadcasting history.
The fifth set of the match was covered by Xan Brooks of the Guardian on their Wimbledon Live Blog and continued the following day by Nicky Bandini.
In the United States, <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a> and sibling channel <a href="ESPN2">ESPN2</a> telecast the match.
